awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Corporate Contributions to Childhood Public Health Outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

Malnutrition and other stressors have been shown to hinder childhood growth and development. In turn, stunted growth is associated with reduced brain development, diminished learning capacity, poor school performance, and declines in long-term career outcomes. In settings characterized by compromised growth and development, corporations may philanthropically contribute resources to assist populations of impacted children. This doctoral dissertation project examines the motivations and practices of private corporations as they insert themselves into domains of public health. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the findings of this research enhances understandings of the effects of privatizing health interventions in disadvantaged communities. In partnership with key stakeholders, this research also generates proposals for how to improve or reconsider these interventions as strategies for addressing broader development priorities.

This research examines how corporate philanthropic programs generate and operationalize knowledge about childhood stunting through community-based interventions, how such knowledge-making sits in dialogue with larger social tensions around identities and development, and how these interventions impact their targeted beneficiaries. The project has multiple objectives. First, the investigators examine variation in the ways that childhood stunting is conceptualized simultaneously as a biological and social problem. Second, the project shows how aspects of identity and heritage are represented in discourse about childhood growth and development. In addition, the practices of corporate philanthropists are examined, specifically the ways they frame the social problems to align with the motivations for interventions. Finally, the investigation examines how private investments in public health interventions affect the growth and development of children. To answer these questions the investigation relies on interviews and direct observations of corporate executives, public health officials, corporate philanthropy administrators and fieldworkers, and targeted beneficiaries of these efforts. In addition, the investigation includes archival research to assess the contexts in which philanthropic efforts impact public health outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examines how the private corporate sector contributes to the prevention of chronic malnutrition and stunted growth in children in Guatemala. Chronic malnutrition has shown to hamper children's expected growth and development. Stunted growth, the visible consequence of chronic malnutrition, is associated with reduced brain development, diminished learning capacity, poor school performance, and decreased income in adult life. The Guatemalan private corporate sector, through their philanthropic foundations, works towards the prevention of chronic malnutrition. This is done by implementing behavioral change interventions, a common public health practice that aims to educate people to change health behaviors. Public health consequences of chronic malnutrition, as well as the active participation of all sectors in its prevention, are well-known by the scientific community, the political sector and civil society. The way in which the private corporate sector understands and participates towards solving this issue is less well understood. Between August 2021 and January 2023, the co-PI completed ethnographic fieldwork at two philanthropic foundations in Guatemala. Interviews with corporate representatives, public health researchers, public officials, and mothers target by the behavioral change interventions designed by these foundations were held. Participant observation in these behavioral change interventions aiming towards prevent chronic malnutrition documented regular activities of these foundations such as personnel training, reports filling, intervention planning, house visits, anthropometric measurement taking, the filling of anthropometric reports, result presentations to community and corporate authorities. As well as the participation in events related to chronic malnutrition prevention not directly related with these two specific foundations. In addition, hemerographic, digital media, and social media research was conducted following the participation of the corporate private sector has in the prevention of chronic malnutrition in the country.

 

This project examined the ways in which the private corporate sector defines chronic malnutrition, its causes, and consequences. As well as exploring leading the role they set themselves up to play in its prevention within the greater Guatemalan social context and their contributions to public health. Related, corporate representatives place big emphasis in the lack of appropriate State services as one of the major causes for the problem of chronic malnutrition in the country and see the private sector as responsible to oversee the government's work on this matter. This project also provides information of the ways in which mothers targeted by these behavioral change interventions interact with new (or reframed) knowledges about chronic malnutrition, nutrition, hygiene practices in the house, and female empowerment. As well as their concerns about more structural problems such as lack of consistent public health services or economic concerns. This research also provides interesting insights about the importance of appropriate field teams to apply behavioral change interventions to prevent chronic malnutrition in public health. Likewise, this work provides information about the nature and difficulties of successful field application of behavioral change interventions aiming to prevent stunting.

 

This project supported the training of a graduate student in sociocultural anthropology and facilitated connections between the co-PI and significant network of actors, among private corporate representatives, public health researchers, and government officials working in the prevention of chronic malnutrition. The co-PI has planned to present her findings to the coordinators at the two foundations that served as primary site for this research and other institutions in the future. Given that chronic malnutrition keeps hindering proper growth and development of a great number of children around the world, this research highlights the relevance of the participation of a sector that has been rarely studied.
